conversation.text: Hi there, I'm going to help you master the  perfect profiterole! Would you like to give it a go?
Absolutely! I love eating them- but have always thought they would be very difficult to make at home.
Ok. I've given you the first step on your profiterole journey. Let's get started; take your time.
Great. Ok, that seems straightforward enough. I've let it cool - now what?
The tricky bit here is beating the mixture really hard until it binds together. Hope you have good biceps!
I'm not really sure if the mixture has come together enough. How can I be sure?
If in doubt- just keeping beating.
evidence: The dough will lump together and there will be a film on the bottom of the pan.

conversation.text: Ah Ok. It's looking good. But it looks very unappetising. What next?
Great, you're doing really well. Now just get those eggs mixed in.
Yeah, thus looks fine. The eggs are well mixed. Am getting some arm ache though- I've only got a wooden spoon!
Is the mixture a fairly thick consistency now?
Yes, I think it looks good. I certainly noticed it thicken up as I beat it. So I'm ready for the next step.
You're doing fantastic! A natural baker by the looks of it. So get the mix onto the baking tray.
That was quite tricky. I made a bit of a mess. Maybe the mix should have been thicker.
I'm sure it's not as bad as you think. Did you use a piping bag or a spoon?
I used a spoon- don't have a bag. They've spread out quite a bit.
But they haven't all pooled together?
Ah no, they are separate blobs. Is that how they should be?
If they are separate blobs then you are doing fine. Not too runny at all.
Whew! Now what do I do?
Ah almost forgot! Did you put the the oven on?
No, I remembered to get the oven on. I'm quite the organised baker.
Now you just need to make those blobs look a bit prettier.
That was easy. They look better now.
We're almost there. It's a very quick bake.
That's good to hear. I'm looking forward to eating them. Baking makes you hungry I'm discovering.
Do you have a skewer to hand?
evidence: Prick each profiterole once with a skewer

conversation.text: Yes, I've just unearthed it from the back of the drawer.
Good- because that step is really important. How are they looking?
evidence: Prick each profiterole once with a skewer

conversation.text: They've really puffed up! Amazing. Wasn't that hopeful that they would.
You need to have faith!
I know. I think I just need to follow your instructions and all will be well.
Did you manage to get them onto the cooling rack OK?
Yes. They are sitting on the rack - looking magnificent if I say so myself. Thanks a million!
Enjoy! So glad it went well for you.
Now all I've got to do is decide on a filling. Decisions, decisions.
That's a whole other story. Cream is a good one if they are really cool.
evidence: Cool on a sheet of baking paper

procedure.summary: Put the water, butter, salt, and sugar in a saucepan.
procedure.description: Bring to a boil, stirring until the butter has melted. Take the saucepan off of the heat and leave to cool slightly for 2-3 minutes.

Add the flour to the butter mixture and beat with a wooden spoon or whisk until everything comes together. Put the saucepan back on the heat and beat vigorously until everything is off the sides of the saucepan. The dough will lump together and there will be a film on the bottom of the pan.

Transfer the mixture to a large bowl or the bowl of a mixer. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well with a wooden spoon or electric mixer after each addition. It may seem like the mixture will not come back together, but don't worry, it will - just keep beating.

Line a baking sheet with parchment paper, then transfer the warm mixture into a pastry bag. Pipe approximately 18-22 drops of pastry onto the baking sheet, about one inch apart. The pastry drops should be about 1 ⁄4 inches (3.2 cm) wide and 1 inch (2.5 cm) high. If you do not have a pastry bag, you can use a spoon to place drops of pastry on the baking sheet.

Moisten your finger with water and use it to lightly press down the swirl at the top of each puff. At this point you can also brush the pastries with egg wash, if you would like them to be shiny after baking.

Place the baking sheet in an oven preheated to 425 °F (218 °C). Bake for 15-20 minutes until they are puffed and golden brown. Prick each profiterole once with a skewer, then return to the oven to dry for about 3 minutes, propping the oven door slightly ajar. Cool on a sheet of baking paper on a wire rack.
